timeline.bodyText: You should make another catch for a InterruptedIOException. You shouldn't attempt a reconnect if you received an interrupt.

replies.bodyText: When catching InterruptedIOException, is it best to call Thread.currentThread().interrupt() or just exit?
replies.author: bobadair

replies.bodyText: It would be best to just exit. Calling Thread.currentThread().interrupt() is only useful if you expect/know that something higher up the call stack is checking for interrupts. Which I don't think is the case here.

timeline.bodyText:
Since this is asynchronous, if this handler is disposed immediately after getting initialized there is a chance it could get disposed before the connection finishes which would result in an illegal state.
The only slow operation you are performing as part of connect is the creation of the SSLSocket. Perhaps you could focus on just making that asynchronous instead.
Another option would be to cancel the future handle interrupt within your connect method.
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText:
Since this is asynchronous, if this handler is disposed immediately after getting initialized there is a chance it could get disposed before the connection finishes which would result in an illegal state.

That’s a good point. I think most bindings that open some sort of network connection use pretty much the same pattern, though. If there is a real possibility of dispose() being called before the async part of initialization is done, maybe the framework should be modified to keep that from happening, or some recommendation should be made in the docs about how best to deal with it?

The only slow operation you are performing as part of connect is the creation of the SSLSocket. Perhaps you could focus on just making that asynchronous instead.

Well, connect() doesn’t do much before creating the the SSL socket and starting the handshake, so I don’t think that would help too much. Even after opening the connection, it just starts a couple of threads and queues a few commands for sending.

Another option would be to cancel the future handle interrupt within your connect method.

I’m not sure what you mean by this. I could save the Future returned by submit and attempt to call cancel on it in dispose(). But are createSocket() and startHandshake() even interruptible? And I assume dispose() would need to wait for connect() to exit before continuing to clean up, but I’m not sure what the best way to do that is.
replies.author: bobadair

replies.bodyText:
But are createSocket() and startHandshake() even interruptible? And I assume dispose() would need to wait for connect() to exit before continuing to clean up, but I’m not sure what the best way to do that is.

You don't necessarily have to interrupt them so much as make sure that any results are silently discarded. You might have to do some synchronous blocks on your asynchronous stuff to make sure that a dispose() followed by an initialize() wouldn't cause some sort of collision on resource access (if it is even possible for such a collision).
replies.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: I just pushed a commit that should take care of this.
replies.author: bobadair

replies.bodyText: Sorry, I've been kind of tied up lately. I looked through that code again, though, and I don't really see any potential problems. Both connect() and disconnect() are synchronized. The dispose() routine calls cancel(true) on the Future running connect(), if it is still running, and then calls disconnect(). So disconnect() will wait for connect() to exit, and then clean up anything it did, including canceling connectRetryJob, keepAliveJob, and keepAliveReconnectJob, and interrupting senderThread and readerThread. It also closes the SSL socket, which would cause senderThread and readerThread to exit regardless. I should check to see if any of those should be declared as volatile to eliminate any potential inter-thread visibility problems, but other that than I don't really see any potential issues with dispose() whenever it's called. Very similar code is being used in this binding's ipbridge and in the alarm decoder binding's ipbridge.
replies.author: bobadair

replies.bodyText: huh, I don't know why I didn't notice that connect and disconnect are synchronized. Yes that would prevent any problems so you can disregard my prior suggestion.
